case_vignette: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a slowly enlarging painless ulcer on his lower lip. One year ago he had a painful rash near his upper lip that resolved completely with acyclovir therapy. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. He has worked in construction for the past 33 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows a 0.5 x 0.5 cm nontender ulcer with everted edges on the midline of his lower lip. The erythematous ulcer bleeds upon palpation. He has numerous moles of varying sizes all over his body. There are no palpable cervical lymph nodes.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've had a slowly growing painless sore on my lower lip for the past three months.
How old are you?
I am 60 years old.
Do you have a history of excessive sun exposure or sunburns?
I have worked in construction for the past 33 years, which has involved being outside often.
Do you use any tobacco products?
Yes, I have smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years.
Have you ever been diagnosed with any skin conditions in the past?
A year ago, I had a painful rash near my upper lip that cleared up with medication.
Are you currently taking any medications for any reason?
I am taking metformin for type 2 diabetes.
Is there a family history of skin cancer or lip lesions?
I'm sorry, but I don't have that information.

Based on your history of sun exposure, tobacco use, and the presence of a painless sore on your lower lip for several months, along with your age and history of diabetes medication, I suspect you may have a squamous cell carcinoma on your lip.

**Final Diagnosis:** Squamous Cell Carcinoma on lower lip
